Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i


>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS/Polaris and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90155738
Short answer: no.
Long answer:
UEFI spec requires the ESP to be FAT32, and better than 99% are. But Windows has trouble (apparently - I've never seen it) with USB flash drives that have multiple partitions.
So, Windows Setup USBs (as generated by the Media Creation Tool) are formatted FAT32 to avoid all possible problems at once.

Before asking for help, please check our list of resources.

0) Install a GNU/Linux distribution of your choice in a Virtual Machine.

2) Dual boot the GNU/Linux distribution of your choice along with Windows or macOS.

    constexpr size_t ThreadCount{ 5 };
    latch doneCounter{ ThreadCount };
    vector<optional<size_t>> data(ThreadCount);
    vector<jthread> threadPool;
    for(size_t i{}; i < ThreadCount; ++i)
    {
        threadPool.emplace_back(jthread([&, i]()
            {
                data[i] = make_data(i);
                doneCounter.count_down();
            }));
    }
    doneCounter.wait();
    cout << "Done.\n";
}

>>90154390
you're not suited to programming. even if you were, a month isn't enough time to generate sufficient evidence that you're a capable enough coder to be worth hiring - nobody will hire someone whose visible projects only started with "hello world" a month ago. you'd be outed by a real programmer in a second within an interview. sucks for you, but the world sucks.

if you want to cram a slice of modern development in to your brain as fast as possible, then figure out how to do the following without asking anyone else (online or in person) for information yourself - rely only on info on sites (eg, manuals) and other people's already-posted questions (eg, stackoverflow):

- set up a virtual machine on your computer. keywords: ubuntu server, vagrant, virtualbox
- install docker on the vm. keywords: apt, docker-ce
- write a simple program in javascript that takes text sent in to it via HTTP and later outputs it when requested, as an HTTP response. keywords: node.js, express, node fs
- "dockerize" the program, so it runs in a container. expose the port express listens on. keywords: docker cli, Dockerfile, EXPOSE
- install nginx on the virtual machine. configure it to listen on port 8080 and reverse-proxy to your program's port. keywords: nginx, reverse proxy, proxy_pass, virtual host
- find your VM's IP. use your browser to send data to your program on the VM's port 8080. then retrieve it back.
- configure docker to run in swarm mode. keywords: docker swarm, swarm init
- create a docker-compose service file that starts 5 replicas of your app service. keywords: docker swarm service file, deploy object, replicas
- use a volume to share the stored data between the instances. keywords: docker-compose volume
- upgrade your app to act like a primitive pastebin. you'll be able to figure it out at this point. keywords: static HTML, HTML form, form POST, node random number generation.

put "wrote fully-scalable pastebin clone" on resume. proceed to get ignored.

#include <errno.h> /* errno (strtoull) */
#include <math.h> /* sqrtl */
#include <stdio.h> /* printf */
#include <stdlib.h> /* malloc rand srand (rand) strtoull */
#include <time.h> /* time (srand) */
#define U64 unsigned long long int
#define F80 long double
int main(int argc, char** argv) {
U64 nrolls, nsides, *count, i;
F80 truemean, mean = 0, stdev = 0, z;
if (argc != 3) { badinput:
  printf("Usage: dice <# of rolls> <# of sides>
Example: dice 1000000000 6
");
  return 1; }
if (argv[1][0] == '-' || argv[2][0] == '-') goto badinput;
nrolls = strtoull(argv[1], 0, 10);
nsides = strtoull(argv[2], 0, 10);
if (nrolls < 1 || nsides < 1 || errno) goto badinput;
if (!(count = malloc(nsides * sizeof(U64)))) {
  printf("Insufficient memory available.
"); return 1; }
printf("Rolling %llu %llu-sided dice...
", nrolls, nsides);
for (i = 0; i < nsides; i++) count[i] = 0;
srand(time(0));
for (i = 0; i < nrolls; i++) count[rand() % nsides]++;
for (i = 0; i < nsides; i++) mean += count[i] * (i + 1);
mean /= nrolls;
for (i = 0; i < nsides; i++)
  stdev += count[i] * (i + 1 - mean) * (i + 1 - mean);
stdev /= nrolls; stdev = sqrtl(stdev);
truemean = ((F80)nsides + 1) / 2;
if (stdev == 0) z = INFINITY;
else z = (mean - truemean) / (stdev / sqrtl(nrolls));
for (i = 0; i < nsides; i++)
  printf("%5llu: %llu
", i + 1, count[i]);
printf(" mean: %8.6Lf
stdev: %8.6Lf
   z: %9.6Lf
", mean, stdev, z);
if (z < -3 || z > 3) printf("Your system's rand() sucks!
");
return 0; }

This is the answer to the "will it replace me" argument. If your job was effectively nothing te begin with, then yes. This is why it goes after white collar middle management first, thereby cleaving into a top and a bottom class.
Ex: Lyft
By getting rid of the people who stand between the person who wants a ride and the ride itself, while still maintaining absolute control over both, Lyft effectively turns "ridesharing" into a new taxi service, sans the dead middle weight. Someday, once self-driving cars are around, they'll simply rewrite the drivers out of the app with a massive price drop and happily slurp up the same amount of cash as their company-owned cars take people from A to B. AI strikes the middle first, then reduces the quantity but does not entirely destroy the worker, whose job becomes to patrol the machine itself. Rideshare workers in the future would still be necessary, for instance, to handle places where the AI had trouble, but that's still a 100 to 1 reduction in workforce. General cybernetics stuff, yaknow?
